content.description: Students design an experiment with a curved, insulated rod of an unknown thermally conducting material, as shown in the figure. The rod is 1 <math alttext="meter" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> long and 2 <math alttext="centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in diameter. One end of the rod is touching the surface of water kept at <math alttext="350 in Kelvin" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mn>350</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> by a hot plate, and the other end is just touching the surface of a well-insulated block of ice.
content.question: The figure shows a graph of the energy transferred by heating from the water through the rod and to the ice over time. If the temperature of the ice is held constant at <math alttext="250 in Kelvin " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>250</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> , what is the thermal conductivity of the rod?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
